key_title: Key to the species of Centrolepis

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the genera of Centrolepidaceae

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Centrolepidaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Conn, B.J. (1994). Centrolepidaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Bracts glabrous, rarely with a few minute triangular hairs on midrib; leaves glabrous
Bracts with long, multicelled rigid hairs on outer surface; leaves hairy or glabrous
Lower bract with an abruptly narrowed, terete, recurved or straight lamina 0.4–8 (–10) mm long; upper bract without a distinct lamina, hence apex obtuse to acute
Lower bract with an abruptly narrowed, ± flattened, straight lamina (8–) 10–45 mm long; upper bract with an abruptly narrowed lamina 3–15 (–22) mm long

Inflorescence unit 3–22 (–40) per pair of bracts, consisting of 1 stamen (or stamen absent) and 3–10 carpels per unit, secondary bracts present or absent; style fused together for up to one-half their length
Inflorescence unit 1 per pair of bracts, consisting of 1 stamen (or stamen absent) and 6–14 carpels, secondary bracts absent; styles only fused at base
Herb forming a dense, compact, rounded tuft; inflorescence borne on an axis 3–9 mm long and flowers usually included amongst the leaves; bracts recurved, 2–4 mm long
Herb tufted, but never forming a compact rounded tuft; inflorescence borne on an axis 2–25 (–40) mm long and flowers usually held above the leaves; bracts straight, 0.4–3 mm long
Bracts with lamina 2–6 mm long and distinctly exceeding the flowers; carpels 2–4 per inflorescence unit
Bracts with lamina 0.5–1 mm long and only just exceeding the flowers; lower bract inserted 0.5–1 mm below upper bract; carpels 5 or 6 per inflorescence unit
